info.title: Computational Toxicology and Exposure (CTX) APIs - CTX Exposure API
info.description: The CTX Exposure API is part of US EPA's Computational Toxicology and Exposure APIs. The CTX Exposure API provides programmtic access to exposure data through a set of endpoints.

tags.name: Functional Use Resource
tags.description: Collection of endpoints with functional use data. Functional use describes a chemical's role in a product or process, which can help determine exposure pathways used to assess chemical exposure. These curated data are sourced from US EPA's Chemicals and Products Database (CPDat).

tags.name: List Presence Resource
tags.description: Collection of endpoints with list presence data, reflecting the occurrence of chemicals on lists present in publicly available documents (sourced from a variety of federal and state agencies and trade associations). These lists are tagged with List Presence Keywords (LPKs) which is a controlled vocabulary developed by EPA that describe broad use information for a chemical useful for general categorization of chemicals across uses, populations, and/or regulatory groups. These curated data are sourced from US EPA's Chemicals and Products Database (CPDat).

tags.name: Product Data Resource
tags.description: Collection of endpoints pertaining to product data. These data provide information on how chemicals are used in commerce or by consumers as well as weight fractions of ingredients in products, where available. These curated data are sourced from US EPA's Chemicals and Products Database (CPDat).

tags.name: httk Data Resource
tags.description: Collection of endpoints with data to support toxicokinetic modeling applications sourced from the US EPA high throughput toxicokinetics `httk` R package. Models to predict toxicokinetics (chemical absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion by the body) are tailored using chemical-specific in vitro data and physiological information.

tags.name: Demographic Exposure Prediction Resource
tags.description: Collection of endpoints with SEEM demographic exposure prediction data. SEEM (Systematic Empirical Evaluation of Models) is a framework developed by the US EPA to predict exposure to chemicals across the general population and demographic subsets of the US.

tags.name: General Exposure Prediction Resource
tags.description: Collection of endpoints for general prediction data. SEEM (Systematic Empirical Evaluation of Models) is a framework developed by the US EPA to predict exposure to chemicals across the general population and demographic subsets of the US.

tags.name: MMDB Resource
tags.description: Collection of endpoints with harmonized data from the Multimedia Monitoring Database (MMDB) to inform on chemical presence in various media like air, water, soil, and human tissues.

tags.name: CCD Data Resource
tags.description: Collection of endpoints used to populate CompTox Chemicals Dashboard (CCD) Exposure tabs.

get.summary: Get Biomonitoring data by DTXSID with CCD projection
get.description: return NHANES inferences data for requested DTXSID. There is an available projection aligned with what's available on the CCD Exposure Biomonitoring tab: ccd-biomonitoring. If no projection is specified, a default CCDBiomonitoring projection will be returned.

parameters.name: projection
parameters.description: Specifies if projection is used. Option: ccd-biomonitoring, If omitted, the default CCDBiomonitoring data is returned.

GenExpoPrediction.description: These are estimates of the average (geometric mean) exposure rate (mg/kg bodyweight/day) for the U.S. population. We are 50% confident that the exposure for the chemical is below the median estimate, and we are 95% confident that the average exposure rate is below the upper 95th percent estimate. Total population predictions are based upon consensus exposure model predictions and the similarity of the compound to those chemicals monitored by NHANES. The method for the total U.S. population was described in a 2018 publication, "Consensus Modeling of Median Chemical Intake for the U.S. Population Based on Predictions of Exposure Pathways".

productionVolume.description: How much chemical is produced or imported in the United States

stockholmConvention.description: Whether (1) or not (0) the chemical is banned by the Stockholm Convention on persistent organic pollutants

probabilityDietary.description: QSPR-predicted probability that the chemical has human exposure via a dietary pathway

probabilityResidential.description: QSPR-predicted probability that the chemical has human exposure via a consumer use pathway

probabilityPesticde.description: QSPR-predicted probability that the chemical has human exposure via a far-field pesticide pathway

probabilityIndustrial.description: QSPR-predicted probability that the chemical has human exposure via a far-field industrial pathway

DemoExpoPrediction.description: These are estimates of the average (geometric mean) exposure rate (mg/kg bodyweight/day) for the U.S. population. We are 50% confident that the exposure for the chemical is below the median estimate, and we are 95% confident that the average exposure rate is below the upper 95th percent estimate. Total population predictions are based upon consensus exposure model predictions and the similarity of the compound to those chemicals monitored by NHANES. The method for the demographic-specific predictions are based upon a simpler, heuristic model described in the 2014 publication "High Throughput Heuristics for Prioritizing Human Exposure to Environmental Chemicals".

demographic.description: Which portion of the U.S. population these values refer to

predictor.description: The model/approach used to make a prediction

l95.description: The lower 95th percentile confidence value (uncertainty) for the prediction

u95.description: The upper 95th percentile confidence value (uncertainty) for the prediction

ad.description: Whether (1) or not (0) the chemical is within the applicability domain of the predictor

reference.description: The peer reviewed journal article explaining how the prediction was made

HttkData.description: The information here describes toxicokinetics in humans. Values are 1) measured either in vitro or in vivo, 2) predicted from chemical properties using in silico tools, or 3) computed with mathematical models simulating toxicokinetics. Note: intrinsic hepatic clearance and fraction unbound in plasma values can have measured values listed, but these may be assumed from measured data using a surrogate species. The Data Source Species column identifies the measured data species source. We use these assumed measured values in calculations to estimate other outcomes, such as volume of distribution, PK half life, and steady-state plasma concentration. The in vitro measured values reflect the value curated for the open source R package “httk”. The computed values are generated with httk using the reported in vitro values. "https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=httk". The in vivo measured values are estimated from toxicokinetic concentration vs. time contained in the CvTdb (https://doi.org/10.1038/s41597-020-0455-1). In vivo estimates are calculated using R package “invivoPKfit” (https://github.com/USEPA/CompTox-ExpoCast-invivoPKfit)

parameter.description: The toxicokinetic parameter. Clint = Intrinsic hepatic clearance rate, Fup = fraction unbound in plasma, Vd = effective volume of distribution, Days.Css = number of days to reach steady-state from constant exposure, Css = plasma concentration after reaching steady-state, TK.Half.Life = number of hours for half of chemical in body to be eliminated

measured.description: Experimentally measured value for the parameter

predicted.description: The predicted value for the parameter

model.description: The toxicokinetic model used to predict the parameter

reference.description: Peer reviewed journal article(s) from which measured or predicted value was derived

percentile.description: For humans, what fraction of the population have a lower value given the same dose. Not relevant to animal species

MMDBSingleSample.description: The information here describes harmonized single-sample records associated with studies that report sample-level results in MMDB with their associated source and metadata information.

id.description: Unique database ID for this individual table record

fullSourceName.description: Full name of the data source

chemicalName.description: Any reported chemical name reported in the raw data

preferredName.description: Preferred chemical name for this DTXSID

result.description: Any reported concentration or sample result included in the raw data (any format)

units.description: Any reported units included in the raw data (any format)

cleanedUnits.description: Units from the raw data formatted for consistency

lod.description: Limit of detection associated witht he study, if available

loq.description: Limit of quantification associated witht he study, if available

detectionFlag.description: Flag indicating if raw data indicated a measurement below limit of detection

resultFlag.description: Any reported flags associated with the reported concentrationresult in the raw data

detected.description: Single variable indicating whether observation is associated with detection of the chemical (1:yes; 2:no; NA:could not be determined conclusively)

detectedConflict.description: A quality flag to note if fields used to determine if a chemical was detected were in conflict, resulting in less certain detected field designation (1:the detected field for a chemical sample is less certain; 0:no conflict)

species.description: Any species name (biota) reported in the raw data

media.description: Any media name reported in the raw data

harmonizedMedium.description: Harmonized medium associated with the reported_media

method.description: Any reported analytical method information included in the raw data (any format)

collectionActivityId.description: Any reported collection activity ID reported in the raw data

sampleId.description: Any reported sample ID reported in the raw data

mmdbSampleId.description: Standardized sample ID issued for unique combinations of sample and source for single-sample data

dates.description: Any reported date of sample collection in the raw data (any format)

location.description: Any specific location reported in the raw data that does not fit other location variables (any format)

stateOrProvince.description: U.S. state or international province where sample was collected

county.description: U.S. county where sample was collected

qualityFlag.description: Flag indicating if raw data included any quality flags for the record

link.description: Any web link to location of the record in the original data source

reference.description: Any literature reference included in the raw data (any format)

exportDate.description: Date this data was inserted into a materialized view

MMDBAggregate.description: The information here describes records associated with reported statistics from aggregate studies in MMDB with their associated source and metadata information.

id.description: Unique database ID for this individual table record

fullSourceName.description: Full name of the data source

chemicalName.description: Any reported chemical name reported in the raw data

preferredName.description: Preferred chemical name for this DTXSID

units.description: Any reported units included in the raw data (any format)

cleanedUnits.description: Units from the raw data formatted for consistency

statistic.description: Name of the reported statistic in the raw data

lod.description: Limit of detection associated witht he study, if available

loq.description: Limit of quantification associated witht he study, if available

numNonDetects.description: Any reported number of nondetects in the raw data

rateDetects.description: Reported rate of detection (percent or fraction) included in the raw data (any format)

detected.description: Single variable indicating whether observation is associated with detection of the chemical (1:yes; 2:no; NA:could not be determined conclusively)

detectedConflict.description: A quality flag to note if fields used to determine if a chemical was detected were in conflict, resulting in less certain detected field designation (1:the detected field for a chemical sample is less certain; 0:no conflict)

species.description: Any species name (biota) reported in the raw data

media.description: Any media name reported in the raw data

harmonizedMedium.description: Harmonized medium associated with the reported_media

population.description: Any reported description of the population studied

subPopulation.description: Any reported subpopulation of human subjects included in the raw data (any format)

collectionActivityId.description: Any reported collection activity ID reported in the raw data

dates.description: Any reported date information for sample collection in the raw data (any format)

years.description: Inclusive year range of sample collection in the raw data (any format)

location.description: Any specific location reported in the raw data that does not fit other location variables (any format)

stateOrProvince.description: U.S. state or international province where sample was collected

county.description: U.S. county where sample was collected

qualityFlag.description: Flag indicating if raw data included any quality flags for the record

link.description: Any web link to location of the record in the original data source

reference.description: Any literature reference included in the raw data (any format)

exportDate.description: Date this data was inserted into a materialized view

api_key.description: Each API request requires an api_key. Contact the CTX API Admin to request an API Key.
api_key.name: x-api-key
